title: Temperature Dependence of Topological Spin Textures in Ferrimagnetic Mn2-xZnxSb Crystal
content: Topologically non-trivial spin textures, such as skyrmions, in ferromagnets have been extensively studied due to their future potential use for information storage and computing. Skyrmions in ferromagnetic materials experience a topological skyrmion Hall effect, which results in a non-colinear motion of the skyrmions in a direction perpendicular to that of the electron current [1]. This phenomenon is not desirable for spintronic devices. However, the skyrmion Hall effect is suppressed in antiferromagnetic and ferrimagnetic materials due to competing magnetic order on different sublattices [2, 3]. Thus, understanding the topological non-trivial spin textures in ferrimagnets is of importance. In this work, we directly visualized topological spin textures as a function of temperature and magnetic field in a ferrimagnetic Mn2-xZnxSb (x=0.85) crystal by using cryogenic Lorentz transmission electron microscopy (LTEM) and magneto-optical Kerr effect (MOKE) microscopy. The crystal structure was also studied at high-resolution using scanning TEM (STEM) high-angle annular dark field (HAADF).
